conclusion: The problem involves analyzing how the shadows (A, B, C, and D) of four objects change in position and size when the light source moves backward above the objects.
The image shows four objects (a sandal, a brick, a cake, and a tall ornament) placed on a surface, each casting a shadow labeled A, B, C, and D respectively.
The shadows have distinct shapes: A (sandal) has an irregular shape, B (brick) is rectangular, C (cake) is round/elliptical, and D (tall ornament) is narrow and elongated.
When the light source moves backward, all four shadows slide toward the observer because the light is farther behind the objects.
As the light source moves backward, every shadow grows longer/larger, with the degree of growth depending on the height of the object.
The shapes of the shadows remain the same (rectangular for the brick, oval for the cake, etc.) despite the changes in size and position.
For object A (sandal), a medium-height object, its shadow shifts forward noticeably and stretches to roughly 1½–2 times its original length.
For object B (brick), a short and blocky object, its rectangular shadow keeps its shape, moves forward slightly, and becomes only slightly longer.
For object C (cake), a very low object, its round/elliptical shadow creeps forward the least and becomes only a bit larger.
For object D (tall ornament), the tallest object, its narrow shadow shifts farthest toward the observer and lengthens the most, becoming significantly larger than the other shadows.
